awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Development of biocompatible and biodegradable UV filters based on food-grade protein sources
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project is the development of novel sunscreens and UV-protective products that are safer for both humans and the environment. Sunscreen protects the skin by absorbing or reflecting the sun’s harmful UV rays,preventing premature skin aging, painful burns, and skin cancer, which is the most common form of cancer in the U.S., and results in treatment costs reaching $3.3 billion annually. UV-filtering active ingredients in sunscreens have been under scrutiny because of the safety risks they pose to humans and the environment. Current UV filters can be absorbed by the skin, cause hormone disruption, and persist and accumulate in the environment, where they can harm wildlife and disrupt marine ecosystems. This project will advance the development of novel sunscreens and UV filters composed of naturally occurring, food-safe peptides containing UV-absorbing amino acids. These compounds are photo-stable, biodegradable, non-absorbing, and safe for both humans and the environment, and they will have high impact in the fields of skin care and biosafe food packaging. Because they can be produced at relatively low cost, they also have the potential to take a considerable share of the $13 billion sunscreen industry.

This SBIR Phase I project proposes to complete the following objectives: 1) Develop sunscreen peptides from widely available food-grade sources and scale to 100 g to show cost-competitiveness with current xenobiotic sunscreen compounds and reproducibility; 2) Optimize peptides to improve their UVabsorbance and investigate heterologous expression in bacteria; and 3) Evaluate peptide chemical 
stability, photo-stability, and confirm non-absorption. This will achieve the overall Phase I goal of reproducibly generating safe and biodegradable UV-absorbing peptides at the 100 g scale, with initial stability studies conducted. This work will lay the foundation for future efforts including independent safety studies, kg-scale production, and clinical trials to result in the first new over-the-counter sunscreen active ingredient introduced in over 35 years.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Soliome has made significant progress in pioneering the first UV protection that is human-inspired and entirely safe for humans and all other life too. In alignment with the NSF’s mission to support high-risk and impactful research, we have successfully developed prototypes and synthetic strategies that provide unmatched safety and performance. Sóliome has progressed from an idea to creating sunscreens that are completely transparent and biocompatible, and most importantly feel luxurious on the skin.

Photoprotection based on compounds that are intrinsic to the human body is a breakthrough in the suncare space, as recognized by early investment from IndieBio and recognition from industry leaders in Sóliome’s first-place finish in the New Material sector (and 2nd place in the Grand Finals out of over 4,000 contestants) at Europe’s leading sustainability conference, Hello Tomorrow.

Our core technology is inspired by how our eyes use amino acids to protect against UV radiation. Kynurenine is a used to block the sun strongest UVA light in our lenses while letting visible light pass through transparently to the retina. Nature has ensured that these filters are highly chemically and photostable, and we are taking its lead.

Unlike all other active ingredients in sunscreens, of which there are about 30 used globally and only eight in the US, Sóliome’s filters are unique in being derived from our own biochemistry, thus being metabolizable by every human cell and all living organisms, degrading only into essential vitamins, fatty acids, and amino acids.

Soliome filters are differentiated from all sunscreen active ingredients, old and new, for being: transparent, photostable, chemically stable, protective against the sun’s brightest UVA light, and safe for all life, including sensitive marine organisms.

A major disadvantage of current sunscreen filters is their difficulty in formulation. Formulation chemists work full-time to navigate these challenges, aiming to produce sunscreens that are stable and effective, while trying to minimize undesirable properties such as greasiness, white cast, heaviness, and drying effects. Adding to this difficulty are strict limits for toxicity and the fact that some UV filters act to degrade others and are thus incompatible.

Soliome has generated IP that covers a vast range of compounds inspired by kynurenine. The difficulty has been in choosing from among the many exceptional compounds to pursue for commercialization. The versatility of our filters allows adjustments across two major dimensions:

Solubility - Naturally derived metabolites can be conjugated to our filters such as fatty acids to make them oil-soluble, like a classic sunscreen, while hydrophilic amino acids can be added to make them water-soluble.

UV range - We have a patent protected modification to our filters that shifts their absorbance from mainly UVA to mainly UVB absorbance, so we can combine both of these into one compound or co-formulate them to create a truly broad-spectrum protective sunscreen with high SPF.

Each filter can combine these two effects of solubility and UV-range, creating a platform of full and effective sun protection—a feat achieved by no other existing technology. This empowers us to create water soluble filters for exceptional skin-feel, and includes oil-soluble sunscreens that act like traditional water-resistant beach sunscreens.

Soliome has reached major milestones in our molecular synthesis. It is not enough to have safe, effective, and luxurious filters if no one can afford to use them. It is also essential that the process we use to make these filters is itself completely safe for the environment.

We have successfully managed to match the pricing of some existing UV technology even at the bench scale. This was achieved by limiting our inputs to only cheap, abundant plant-based products that are readily available at the ton-scale. This is essential as the US economy shifts away from petroleum-based inputs. Sóliome will continue to lead the way in developing suncare and skincare products that utilize exclusively bio-based inputs.

Each of our candidate filters requires synthetic optimization, and we are extremely proud to have developed a process for our lead filters that is entirely green, utilizing only safe solvents (in many steps even just water), eliminating the risk of harmful by-products. Our environmentally conscious approach safeguards against contamination risks, such as those that recently have occurred with benzene in some SPF products.

The National Science Foundation’s early backing has been pivotal in realizing the future of human-inspired and entirely safe photoprotection. Our technical progress has laid the foundation for commercialization success through additional investment and talent. Sóliome will continue this success as we move to intensive safety validation and scaled manufacturing, remaining committed to our mission of ensuring widespread access to a new generation of sunscreens that are both highly effective and delightful to wear.


Last Modified: 10/13/2023
Modified by: Micah Nelp
